keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and fled the U.S. by faking his death in 2020.
He was identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, part of Utah’s effort to clear its backlog of uninvestigated cases.
An online obituary falsely claimed he died in 2020, but investigations by police, his former lawyer, and a foster family revealed he was not dead.
Rossi was arrested in Scotland in 2021 while receiving treatment for COVID-19 due to distinctive tattoos recognized from an Interpol notice.
He was extradited to Utah in January 2024 after a lengthy legal battle and pleaded not guilty during sentencing, maintaining his innocence.
He used at least a dozen aliases over the years to evade capture and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
FBI is also investigating fraud charges in Ohio related to sex-related offenses from 2008.
The victim in the first case testified that Rossi pressured her to pay for dates and car repairs, and later raped her in his bedroom after an engagement.
The second rape case resulted in a separate conviction in September 2025, with sentencing scheduled for November 4.
A Utah judge sentenced Rossi to five years to life in prison, emphasizing that he is a 'serial abuser' and a 'flight risk.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog, he attempted to evade justice by faking his death in 2020, with an online obituary claiming he died of lymphoma. He was later arrested in Scotland in 2021 due to distinctive tattoos recognized by Interpol, and extradited to Utah in January 2024. A Utah judge sentenced him to five years to life in prison, calling him a 'serial abuser' and 'flight risk.' The victims testified about financial manipulation and abuse during their relationships, with one describing the trauma as a 'trail of fear and pain.' Rossi, who had used at least a dozen aliases, maintained his innocence during sentencing. He previously faced sex offender registration issues in Rhode Island and fraud charges in Ohio. This case underscores the importance of forensic DNA databases, international law enforcement cooperation, and accountability for serial predators.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
